    Treatment with azithromycin was associated with a reduced risk of S aureus acquisition (OR 0.38, 95% CI 0.23 to 0.61; 6 studies, 552 participants; I2 = 3%; Analysis 1.10) (COMBAT CF 2022; Clement 2006; OPTIMIZE 2018; Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010; Steinkamp 2007). This result includes different time points. The planned sensitivity analysis where authors excluded data from Steinkamp 2007 (the only study with a high risk of bias in any domain), showed no difference in the magnitude of effect.

    One study reported fewer events after two months (OR 0.05, 95% CI 0.00 to 0.99; 1 study, 31 participants; Analysis 1.10) (Steinkamp 2007), whilst two studies reported the same effect after six months (OR 0.31, 95% CI 0.14 to 0.71; 2 studies, 240 participants; Analysis 1.10) (Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010).

    Clement 2006 reported that there was no difference in the acquisition of S aureus after 12 months (OR 0.19, 95% CI 0.02 to 1.70; 1 study, 82 participants; Analysis 1.10). Similarly, no difference in the acquisition of S aureus was seen after 18 months (OR 0.65, 95% CI 0.28 to 1.49; 1 study, 94 participants; Analysis 1.10) (OPTIMIZE 2018), or 36 months (OR 0.43, 95% CI 0.14 to 1.28; 1 study, 105 participants; Analysis 1.10) (COMBAT CF 2022).

    Two of these studies also looked at the number of participants with S aureus who had eradicated these bacteria at the end of the study (Clement 2006; Saiman 2003). Treatment with azithromycin was not associated with increased eradication (OR 1.94, 95% CI 0.92 to 4.10; 2 studies, 220 participants; I² = 41%; Analysis 1.11).

    Saiman 2010 (n = 165) reported an increased risk of acquiring macrolide‐resistant S aureus for those participants on azithromycin (OR 5.01, 95% CI 2.14 to 11.71; Analysis 1.12).

    There was no evidence of increased risk of acquiring MRSA at any time point following treatment with azithromycin compared to placebo (OR 1.02, 95% CI 0.56 to 1.86; 5 studies, 755 participants; I² = 0%; Analysis 1.13).

    c. H influenzae

    Four studies reported on the acquisition of H influenzae at different time points; at six months (Saiman 2010), 12 months (Clement 2006), 18 months (OPTIMIZE 2018), or 36 months (COMBAT CF 2022). Combined data showed no difference between placebo and azithromycin (OR 0.97, 95% CI 0.57 to 1.64; 4 studies, 611 participants; I² = 0%; Analysis 1.14). None of these studies had a high risk of bias in any domain, so we did not undertake the planned sensitivity analysis.

    The second Saiman study (n = 240) reported acquisition of macrolide‐resistant H influenzae in 10 participants in the azithromycin group compared to one participant in the placebo group (OR 10.09, 95% CI 1.27 to 80.09; Analysis 1.15) (Saiman 2010).

    d. Other significant pathogens

    There was no evidence of emergence of gram‐negative bacteria or other significant CF pathogens. Six studies reported that culture for non‐tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) was undertaken on sputum samples and there was no evidence of emergence of this bacteria in participants treated with azithromycin (Clement 2006; Equi 2002; Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010; Wolter 2002). Only two studies reported data that we could analyse (OPTIMIZE 2018; Saiman 2003), with results showing no difference in recognised treatment‐emergent NTM (OR 0.35, 95% CI 0.06 to 1.95; 2 studies, 206 participants; I² = 0%; Analysis 1.16). In Saiman 2010, NTM was cultured on screening for one participant, who was subsequently discontinued from study drug (placebo) but included in the analysis.

    4. Additional treatment required (courses or days of treatment)

    a. Oral antibiotics

    Five studies reported the need for extra oral antibiotics (Equi 2002; Nichols 2020; OPTIMIZE 2018; Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010). There was no difference between groups after six weeks (OR 0.51, 95% CI 0.18 to 1.42; 1 study, 115 participants; Analysis 1.17) (Nichols 2020). However, after six months treatment with azithromycin, fewer participants required additional oral antibiotics (OR 0.28, 95% CI 0.19 to 0.42; 3 studies, 527 participants; I² = 0%; Analysis 1.17) (Equi 2002; Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010). Results from a single study showed no difference between groups after 18 months of azithromycin treatment (OR 0.71, 95% CI 0.40 to 1.25; 1 study, 221 participants; Analysis 1.17) (OPTIMIZE 2018).

    Clement 2006 (n = 82) reported the number of additional courses of oral antibiotics and the number of days of oral antibiotics. Investigators found that 12 months' treatment with azithromycin led to a reduction in both the number of courses (MD ‐1.70 courses, 95% CI ‐1.90 to ‐1.50; Analysis 1.18) and in the days of treatment (MD ‐12.00 days, 95% CI ‐17.63 to ‐6.37; Analysis 1.19).

    b. Intravenous antibiotics

    Five studies reported the need for intravenous antibiotic treatment (Analysis 1.20) and did not demonstrate a difference between azithromycin or placebo at six weeks (OR 1.34 courses, 95% CI 0.22 to 8.37; 1 study, 115 participants) (Nichols 2020), at six months (OR 0.78 courses, 95% CI 0.49 to 1.23; 3 studies, 527 participants; I² = 9%; high‐certainty evidence) (Equi 2002; Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010), or at 18 months (OR 1.01 courses, 95% CI 0.53 to 1.94; 1 study, 221 participants) (OPTIMIZE 2018).

    Clement 2006 reported analysable data showing a reduction in both the mean number of courses of intravenous antibiotics (MD ‐0.80 courses, 95% CI ‐0.94 to ‐0.66; 1 study, 82 participants; Analysis 1.21) and the mean number of days of intravenous antibiotics (MD ‐12.00 days, 95% CI ‐13.96 to ‐10.04; 1 study, 82 participants; Analysis 1.22) over 12 months.

    Wolter 2002 reported fewer courses of intravenous antibiotic treatment with azithromycin (mean number of courses = 0.4, range zero to two courses) versus placebo (mean number of courses = 1.1, range zero to seven courses) (P < 0.016). The same study also reported fewer days of intravenous antibiotic treatment with azithromycin (mean number of days = 2.0, range 0 to 14 days) versus placebo (mean number of days = 7.1, range 0 to 44 days) (Wolter 2002).

    5. Development of ABPA

    The earlier Saiman study reported an increased incidence of wheeze in the azithromycin group, but no other evidence of ABPA (Saiman 2003). One participant treated with azithromycin in the Clement 2006 study was diagnosed with ABPA and withdrawn from the study (OR 0.34, 95% CI 0.01 to 8.63; 1 study, 82 participants; Analysis 1.23).

    6. Nutritional markers

    BMI

    Overall, the reporting of nutritional parameters was limited. The Clement 2006 study measured the change in BMI z score after 12 months and found no difference between participants treated with azithromycin and placebo (MD 0.15, 95% CI ‐0.03 to 0.33; 1 study, 82 participants; Analysis 1.24). COMBAT CF 2022 calculated a mean BMI score at age three years (end of the study period); investigators reported no difference between azithromycin and placebo (MD 0.40, 95% CI ‐0.09 to 0.89; 1 study, 98 participants; Analysis 1.25). One study narratively reported no significant change in BMI (Wolter 2002).

    Weight

    Four studies measured the change in weight from baseline at different time points (Nichols 2020; OPTIMIZE 2018; Saiman 2003; Saiman 2010). After six weeks of azithromycin or placebo, Nichols 2020 found no difference between groups (MD 0.25 kg, 95% CI ‐0.29 to 0.79; 1 study, 108 participants; Analysis 1.26). After six months, both Saiman 2003 and Saiman 2010 reported a greater weight gain in participants receiving azithromycin (MD 0.62 kg, 95% CI 0.26 to 0.98; 2 studies, 445 participants; I² = 0%; Analysis 1.26). After 18 months of azithromycin, the OPTIMIZE 2018 study found little difference between groups for the change in weight (MD 1.27 kg, 95% CI 0.01 to 2.52; Analysis 1.26).

    7. Liver disease

    There were no reports of significant liver involvement from any study.

    Transient increases in liver transaminases were reported in some studies, but infrequently and with no increased risk for participants treated with azithromycin (Equi 2002; Saiman 2003). Three participants in the Caparros‐Martin study discontinued the study medication due to elevated liver enzyme concentrations (two in the azithromycin group and one in the placebo group) (COMBAT CF 2022).

    8. QoL

    Nine studies assessed QoL via a questionnaire (COMBAT CF 2022; Clement 2006; McCormack 2007; O'Connor 2009; Nichols 2020; OPTIMIZE 2018; Saiman 2003; Steinkamp 2007; Wolter 2002). Five studies used language‐appropriate versions of the CFQ or CFQ‐R (Clement 2006; Nichols 2020; O'Connor 2009; Saiman 2003; Steinkamp 2007) or Cystic Fibrosis Respiratory Symptom Diary ‐ Chronic Respiratory Infection Symptom Score (CFRSD‐CRISS) (Nichols 2020; OPTIMIZE 2018). These results are presented below.

    One study used the Chronic Respiratory Disease Questionnaire (which is not validated in CF) and narratively reported improvements in dyspnoea, emotional, mastery and total scores for all participants, but these were greater in the azithromycin group; also, improved fatigue scores were only seen in the azithromycin group (Wolter 2002). COMBAT CF 2022 used an unspecified QoL scale and reported no difference in QoL outcomes apart from the physical well‐being domain in which the azithromycin group scored better (MD 4.7 points, 95% CI 0.6 to 8.9). A third study reported on subjective well‐being and found no difference between groups (Equi 2002).

    CFQ‐R

    Clement 2006 narratively reported no difference in any domain at 12 months; whilst O'Connor 2009 narratively reported an improvement in the vitality and physical functioning domains when comparing the azithromycin arm to the placebo arm of the cross‐over study.

    Overall score

    Only the earlier Saiman study reported on the change in total QoL score; at six months there was no difference between groups (MD 1.60, 95% CI ‐0.61 to 3.81; 1 study, 177 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.27).

    Physical domain

    After two months, Steinkamp 2007 found no difference in the physical domain of the CFQ‐R score (MD 8.40, 95% CI ‐8.25 to 25.05; 1 study, 28 participants; Analysis 1.28). After six months, Saiman 2003 found an improvement in this domain in the azithromycin group compared to a decrease in score in the placebo group (MD 2.70, 95% CI 0.09 to 5.31; Analysis 1.28). When these data were combined, there was a greater improvement with azithromycin compared to placebo (MD 2.84, 95% CI 0.26 to 5.42; 2 studies, 205 participants; Analysis 1.28).

    Respiratory symptoms domain

    Nichols 2020 reported a summary statistic showing no difference in overall CFQ‐R respiratory symptom score between groups after six weeks (MD 1.53 points, 95% CI ‐3.70 to 6.77. After two months, Steinkamp 2007 reported an improved respiratory symptom score in the azithromycin group compared to placebo (MD 15.40, 95% CI 2.16 to 28.64; 1 study, 26 participants; Analysis 1.29).

    Psychosocial domain

    Two studies reported on this domain, Steinkamp 2007 at two months and Saiman 2003 at six months. There was no difference in the psychosocial domain between azithromycin and placebo either individually or when data were combined (MD 0.08 (95% CI ‐3.14 to 3.30; 2 studies, 204 participants; Analysis 1.30)).

    Body image domain

    The same two studies reported on the body image domain (Saiman 2003; Steinkamp 2007). Again, there was no difference found, either individually or when data were combined (MD 2.73, 95% CI ‐0.54 to 6.01; 2 studies, 205 participants; Analysis 1.31).

    Eating disorder domain

    After two months, Steinkamp 2007 reported improvements in the azithromycin group compared to placebo for the eating disorder domain (MD 13.70, 95% CI 0.79 to 26.61; 1 study, 27 participants; Analysis 1.32).

    Problems with weight domain

    Similarly, after two months, Steinkamp 2007 found an improvement in the azithromycin group compared to a decrease in score in the placebo group for this domain (MD 35.20, 95% CI 14.82 to 55.58; 1 study, 26 participants; Analysis 1.33).

    CFRSD‐CRISS

    Two studies assessed QoL using the CFRSD‐CRISS scale; neither found any difference between the azithromycin and the placebo groups after either six weeks using absolute change in points (MD −2.89 points, 95% CI −7.01 to 1.22; 1 study, 119 participants) (Nichols 2020) or after 18 months as a percentage change in score (MD ‐0.26%, 95% CI ‐6.38 to 5.85; 1 study, 221 participants) (OPTIMIZE 2018).

    10. Changes in inflammatory markers

    a. BAL or sputum

    Two studies reported on levels of the inflammatory markers IL‐8 and neutrophil elastase (COMBAT CF 2022; Equi 2002). COMBAT CF 2022 found lower levels with azithromycin of both IL‐8 (MD ‐1.20 pg/mL, 95% CI ‐1.88 to ‐0.52; 1 study, 103 participants; Analysis 1.34) and neutrophil elastase (MD ‐0.70 µg/mL, 95% CI ‐1.19 to ‐0.21; 1 study, 103 participants; Analysis 1.35) after 36 months. The Equi study found no difference in the median absolute difference between groups for either IL‐8 or neutrophil elastase (Equi 2002).

    b. Blood

    One study reported that treatment with azithromycin had an effect on the time trend of the inflammatory marker C‐reactive protein (CRP) (P < 0.001) over three months. Median values for CRP were stated to have fallen in the azithromycin group but to have remained stable in the placebo group (Wolter 2002).

    In a further study, participants were randomised following a two‐week course of IV antibiotics (Steinkamp 2007). Over the eight‐week study period, CRP increased in both treatment arms; while this was not significantly more in the placebo group in our analysis (Analysis 1.36), this was reported as a significant difference in favour of azithromycin in the original published paper.

    The 12‐week Rotschild study examined antibodies against bactericidal or permeability‐increasing protein (BPI‐ANCA) and found no difference following treatment with placebo or azithromycin (Rotschild 2005).

    The later Saiman study measured serum inflammatory markers at baseline, day 28 and day 168 of the study (Saiman 2010). Investigators reported small but significant reductions in serum myeloperoxidase, absolute neutrophil count and CRP in children treated with azithromycin at day 28, but not at day 168 (Ratjen 2012). Due to the skewed distribution of the inflammatory markers, logarithmically transformed values were presented in the paper; for this reason, these data have not been included in this review.

    High‐dose azithromycin compared to low‐dose azithromycin

    We included one study with 47 participants (children aged five to 18) in this comparison of high‐dose oral azithromycin (15 mg/kg/day) with low‐dose oral azithromycin (5 mg/kg/day) (Kabra 2010). The treatment period was six months and investigators followed participants for 12 months. The results are summarised in summary of findings Table 2.

    Primary outcomes
    1. Lung function

    a. FEV1

    The investigators reported within‐group differences for FEV1, stating there was no difference in mean FEV1 % predicted between baseline and six months in either group. However, in the high‐dose group, there was a significant decline in FEV1 % predicted from baseline at nine, 12 and 18 months (Kabra 2010). We graded the certainty of evidence as very low.

    b. FVC

    FVC was stated as being comparable between groups at baseline and six months, but the data were not presented (Kabra 2010).

    c. Non‐routine tests

    Similarly, FEF25-75 and peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) were also reported as being comparable between groups, but the data were not presented (Kabra 2010).

    2. Respiratory exacerbations

    There was no difference in the number of pulmonary exacerbations between the high‐dose and the low‐dose groups at six months (MD ‐0.05, 95% CI ‐0.20 to 0.10; Analysis 2.1) (Kabra 2010). We graded the certainty of evidence as very low.

    3. Survival

    No deaths were reported (Kabra 2010).

    Secondary outcomes
    3. Acquisition or eradication of significant CF pathogens

    a. P aeruginosa

    The study reported that the number of children positive for P aeruginosa over the course of the study was similar between groups, but the investigators did not report how many cases were newly emergent (Kabra 2010).

    b. S aureus (including MRSA)

    The distribution of S aureus was reported to be similar in the two groups (Kabra 2010).

    d. Other significant pathogens

    The study also reported on Streptococcus haemolyticus , Streptococcus pneumoniae and Candida albicans; all organisms were reported to be similarly distributed in the two groups (Kabra 2010).

    6. Nutritional markers

    There was no difference in weight at either three months (MD 1.30 kg, 95% CI ‐7.12 to 9.72) or six months (MD ‐2.00 kg, 95% CI ‐10.75 to 6.75) (Kabra 2010).

    Nebulised azithromycin compared to oral azithromycin

    One study (45 participants) compared nebulised azithromycin to oral azithromycin (Maneshi 2019). The data for most of the outcomes were presented as baseline and endpoint values, but the SD for the change was not given. For this reason, we have not been able to analyse the data in this review, but reported the treatment effects directly from the paper, which does give the difference between the mean changes in each group. The results are summarised in summary of findings Table 3.

    Primary outcomes
    1. Lung function

    a. FEV1

    Mean change from baseline in FEV1 % predicted was reported to be 5.89% (P < 0.001) higher in the nebulised azithromycin group compared to the oral azithromycin group (Maneshi 2019). We judged the certainty of evidence to be very low.

    3. Survival

    No deaths were reported.

    Secondary outcomes
    1. Adverse effects

    a. Mild

    Adverse events were reported narratively in the paper. The authors stated that there were no cases of intolerance following a test dose of azithromycin. Productive cough was reported more frequently in the nebulised azithromycin group; while diarrhoea, abdominal cramp, and heartburn were reported more frequently in the oral azithromycin group (Maneshi 2019). We judged the certainty of evidence to be very low.

    3. Acquisition or eradication of significant CF pathogens

    a. P aeruginosa

    The mean change in P aeruginosa count was greater in the nebulised group and there was a greater decline in levels after 28 days (MD ‐0.5 log10 CFU/g sputum (P < 0.001)), which was described as significant (Maneshi 2019). This result was statistically significant, but there is no recognised minimal clinically important difference (MCID) for the number of CFUs. We judged the certainty of evidence to be very low.

    6. Nutritional markers

    There was a greater increase in both weight (MD 0.56 kg, P = 0.001) and BMI (MD 0.23, P = 0.005) in the nebulised azithromycin group compared to the oral group (Maneshi 2019).

    8. QoL

    The study reported QoL using the PEDsQL‐4 scale and reported that QoL improved in both groups, but there was a greater mean improvement in the nebulised azithromycin group compared to the oral azithromycin group (MD ‐5.00, P < 0.001) (Maneshi 2019). However, a higher score using the PEDsQL‐4 scale indicated a better QoL; the scores presented in Table 2 of the original paper showed that scores decreased from baseline in both the oral and nebulised groups, albeit the decrease was less with oral azithromycin. In our view, this does not constitute an improvement in QoL and the narrative description in the paper contradicts the data presented in the table. We judged the certainty of the evidence to be very low.

    Weekly azithromycin compared to daily azithromycin

    One large Australian study with 208 participants compared daily versus weekly dosing regimens of azithromycin (McCormack 2007). The results are summarised in summary of findings Table 4.

    Primary outcomes
    1. Lung function

    a. FEV1

    The relative change in FEV1 % predicted was greater in the daily azithromycin group compared to the weekly dose at one month (MD ‐0.40% predicted, 95% CI ‐0.60 to ‐0.20; Analysis 3.1), at three months (MD ‐1.20% predicted, 95% CI ‐1.40 to ‐1.00; Analysis 3.1), and at six months (MD ‐0.70% predicted, 95% CI ‐0.95 to ‐0.45; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.1) (McCormack 2007). Our analysis of the data favoured daily dosing at all reported time points; this disagrees with the paper which concluded that there was no difference between the two regimens, thus proving equivalence (McCormack 2007).

    b. FVC

    Investigators stated that there was no difference between treatment groups at any time point for FVC, but did not present data (McCormack 2007).

    2. Respiratory exacerbations

    Our analysis showed a longer time until the first respiratory exacerbation in the weekly‐dose group (MD 17.30 days, 95% CI 4.32 days to 30.28 days; Analysis 3.2). However, these results were not consistent with the original authors' report, which suggested the difference was not significant (P = 0.17). The authors have been contacted for clarification, but we have not yet received a reply.

    3. Survival

    No deaths were reported (McCormack 2007).

    Secondary outcomes
    1. Adverse effects

    a. Mild

    Participants taking azithromycin weekly were more likely to have gastrointestinal adverse events (OR 3.62, 95% CI 1.61 to 8.14; Analysis 3.3), but there were no differences in total adverse effects (OR 1.58, 95% CI 0.85 to 2.91; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.3) or abnormal liver transaminases (OR 0.24, 95% CI 0.85 to 2.91; Analysis 3.3) (McCormack 2007).

    b. Moderate

    There was no difference in the number of participants who discontinued treatment (OR 2.53, 95% CI 0.86 to 7.46; Analysis 3.3) (McCormack 2007).

    2. Number of days in hospital

    The study did not demonstrate any difference between weekly and daily dosing with respect to the time spent in hospital (MD 0.00 days, 95% CI ‐2.97 to 2.97; Analysis 3.4) or the number of hospital admissions (MD 0.00 admissions, 95% CI ‐0.25 to 0.25; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.5) (McCormack 2007).

    3. Acquisition or eradication of significant CF pathogens

    a. P aeruginosa

    The study reported only that P aeruginosa was found in 66% of participants' sputum at baseline, that there was no difference between the weekly and daily groups, and that this percentage did not change over the course of the study (McCormack 2007).

    b. S aureus (including MRSA)

    McCormack 2007 reported that a number of participants acquired azithromycin‐resistant S aureus,although there was no difference between groups (OR 0.65, 95% CI 0.11 to 3.96; Analysis 3.6).

    c. H influenzae

    There were no isolates of H influenzae after six months (McCormack 2007).

    d. Other significant pathogens

    After six months of treatment, there were no new isolates of B cepacia (McCormack 2007).

    6. Nutritional markers

    BMI

    There was no difference between groups in the change in BMI (adults) or BMI z scores (children) after six months of treatment (McCormack 2007).

    Weight

    There was a slight difference favouring the daily group in weight z scores in participants aged less than 18 years (McCormack 2007).

    8. QoL

    CFQ

    There was an improvement in the physical domain of the CFQ in the weekly group (8.2 points, P = 0.02) and parents of children younger than 14 years reported higher scores for the health domain in the daily group. There were no differences in any other domain (McCormack 2007). We judged the certainty of evidence to be moderate for this outcome.

    10. Changes in inflammatory markers

    a. Blood

    The study demonstrated a greater fall in CRP (though not clinically relevant) in the daily compared to the weekly treatment group at one month (MD 2.10, 95% CI 1.70 to 2.50; Analysis 3.7), three months (MD 5.20, 95% CI 4.71 to 5.69; Analysis 3.7), and six months (MD 5.10, 95% CI 4.70 to 5.50; Analysis 3.7) (McCormack 2007).

    Discussion

    Summary of main results

    We included 14 studies in this updated review with 1467 participants (both children and adults). Of these, two studies were of a cross‐over design and the remaining 12 were of a parallel design. All the studies looked at the effects of azithromycin: 11 compared oral azithromycin to matched placebo; one study compared high‐dose azithromycin (15 mg/kg/day) with low‐dose azithromycin (5 mg/kg/day) given orally; one study compared nebulised with oral azithromycin; and the final study compared a weekly oral dose of azithromycin to a daily dose.

    Oral azithromycin compared to placebo

    Azithromycin slightly improves FEV1 % predicted compared to placebo at one, two and six months compared to placebo, although there was no difference seen at three months, four months or 12 months. Pulmonary exacerbations were recorded in different ways across the studies, but data reported at one, three, six and 12 months demonstrated that participants on azithromycin were more likely to be free of exacerbation. There was also moderate‐certainty evidence of a decreased risk of developing an exacerbation in the azithromycin group compared to the placebo group.

    Mild adverse events were common across the studies, but there was mostly no difference between groups. Adverse events more common in the azithromycin group included nausea and wheezing. Adverse events more common in the placebo group included cough and fever. There were no deaths or life‐threatening adverse events in any of the included studies.

    There was no difference in the number of hospital admissions at six months or in the acquisition of new P aeruginosa infection at 12 months or over. Neither was there a difference in the need for extra intravenous antibiotics or QoL score.

    High‐dose azithromycin (15 mg/kg/day) compared to low‐dose azithromycin (5 mg/kg/day)

    The single study comparing a high dose of azithromycin to a low dose only included children. We are uncertain whether there is any difference between the two groups in either FEV1 % predicted at six months or in the rate of exacerbations per child per month. The study did not report on any of our other clinically important outcomes: adverse events; hospitalisations; new acquisition of P aeruginosa; need for additional antibiotics; or QoL.

    Nebulised azithromycin compared to oral azithromycin

    The single study for this comparison again only included children and we graded the certainty of the evidence across all outcomes to be very low. We were unable to include any data in our analyses and have reported findings directly from the paper. The authors reported that there was a greater mean change in FEV1 % predicted at one month in the nebulised azithromycin group (P < 0.001), but they did not report on excacerbations. In terms of adverse events, productive cough was reported more frequently in the nebulised azithromycin group whilst diarrhoea, abdominal cramp, and heartburn were reported more frequently in the oral azithromycin group; we judged the certainty of this evidence as very low. The authors also reported that there was a greater decline in P aeruginosa count in the nebulised treatment group (P < 0.001) as well as a greater improvement in QoL score. The study did not report on hospitalisations or need for additional antibiotics.

    Weekly azithromycin compared to daily azithromycin

    The single study included in this comparison provided moderate‐certainty evidence for weekly compared to daily azithromycin. There is probably a lower mean change in FEV1 % predicted at six months in the weekly group compared to the daily group, but there is probably also a longer period of time until first exacerbation in the weekly group. There was no difference between groups in adverse events although gastrointestinal adverse events are probably more common in the weekly group. There was no difference between groups in the mean number of admissions to hospital or in QoL scores, except for the physical domain where there was probably a greater improvement in the weekly azithromycin group. The need for additional antibiotics was not reported and P aeruginosa was only reported as a frequency at baseline and did not report newly identified cases.

    Overall completeness and applicability of evidence

    We are confident that we have identified all the studies that attempt to answer our review question; however, we have not been able to include studies of macrolide antibiotics other than azithromycin. We excluded studies looking at the effects of clarithromycin (Barker 2005; Dogru 2004; Frederiksen 2001; Kessaris 2003; Ordonez 2001; Pukhalsky 2001; Sriram 2003) and roxithromycin (Dionyssopoulou 2005), due to a lack of information or inappropriate study design. These studies were over 15 years old with no studies carried out more recently.

    The combined data from the azithromycin studies can provide us with confidence concerning the impact on respiratory function and other more pragmatic outcomes, such as the need for oral antibiotics and risk of respiratory exacerbation. The studies enroled a broad range of participants over the age of six years, with and without chronic P aeruginosa airway infection. To date, 1467 children and adults have been enroled in RCTs evaluating azithromycin for treating people with CF. In previous versions of this review, we were not able to include any studies of children younger than six years of age. In this update, we have included two studies with younger children (COMBAT CF 2022; OPTIMIZE 2018), giving a more complete picture of the effectiveness of macrolide antibiotics. This is particularly pertinent following the expansion of newborn screening for CF and the discrepancy in the advice regarding the need for long‐term antibiotic prophylaxis in these infants (Rosenfeld 2020).

    A potentially confounding variable to be considered is chronic infection of the airways with P aeruginosa . One study enroled people with CF and chronic P aeruginosa infection (Saiman 2003) and one study without (Saiman 2010); other studies have enroled both populations. While the later Saiman study did not demonstrate a significant improvement in the primary outcome of relative change in FEV1, when these data were included in our meta‐analysis, they did not change the overall result after six months and were consistent with other study results (Saiman 2010). In the Clement study, subgroup analysis of participants with and without chronic P aeruginosa infection did not alter the overall results, although data at six months were not presented (Clement 2006).

    In terms of outcomes, only one study did not report on our primary outcome of change in FEV1 (COMBAT CF 2022). This study included infants from birth to 36 months of age and spirometry in this age group would be inappropriate. Only nine of our studies reported on exacerbations and they measured exacerbations in various different ways (number with an exacerbation, exacerbation rate, time to first exacerbation etc.), making it difficult to combine data. Similarly, with adverse events, these were categorised and reported in different ways, making synthesis difficult.

    None of our included studies reported on liver disease and whilst QoL was measured in most of the studies, none reported specifically on treatment burden.

    Overall, there is no sufficient evidence to advocate azithromycin therapy in any particular subgroup of people with CF (for example, children over six years of age or those with chronic P aeruginosa airway infection).

    Quality of the evidence

    We have presented the certainty of evidence by outcome for each of the comparisons included in the review in the summary of findings tables (summary of findings Table 1; summary of findings Table 2; summary of findings Table 3; summary of findings Table 4).

    Oral azithromycin compared to placebo

    We included 11 studies in this comparison, although we were not able to combine data from all the studies. Despite this, we graded the certainty of evidence as moderate to high. There was little risk of bias in the design of the studies and there were sufficient numbers of participants to be applicable to the more general CF population for our primary outcomes. We downgraded the certainty of evidence for pulmonary exacerbations and new acquisition of P aeruginosa because the studies contributing data were conducted in a paediatric population and the findings may not apply to an adult population. We also downgraded the certainty of evidence for adverse events due to heterogeneity in the way that these were measured and reported. We downgraded the certainty of evidence for QoL measurement as there was only one study reporting this outcome which reduced the number of participants contributing data (summary of findings Table 1). We undertook sensitivity analyses on two of our analyses, where we combined data from at least four studies and excluded any study which had a high risk of bias in any domain assessed (Analysis 1.1; Analysis 1.10). We excluded Steinkamp 2007, which had a high risk of other potential bias, but in both analyses the magnitude of the treatment effect remained the same.

    High‐dose azithromycin compared to low‐dose azithromycin

    We were only able to include one study for this comparison; the study reported data for only two of our outcomes (FEV1 % predicted and pulmonary exacerbations). We judged that the certainty of evidence for this comparison was very low due to risk of bias within the single study, imprecision due to low participant numbers, and indirectness as the study only included children (summary of findings Table 2).

    Nebulised azithromycin compared to oral azithromycin

    The certainty of evidence for this comparison was very low due to: firstly, the risk of bias within the single included study, particularly across the domains of randomisation, blinding and completeness of data; imprecision due to low participant numbers; and indirectness as the results were only applicable to a paediatric population.

    Weekly azithromycin compared to daily azithromycin

    We judged the certainty of evidence for this comparison to be moderate despite there only being one included study. We downgraded the evidence only for imprecision due to low participant numbers.

    Potential biases in the review process

    We are confident that all eligible studies have been identified, and we contacted authors for additional information where necessary.

    Two new authors (SS, DK) joined the author team for this update and carried out the searches, screening and data extraction. However, previously included studies were reviewed when adding the new data and there was liaison with the authors of the previous review versions.

    In this update, we have split the review into four comparisons as we felt that the results were more reflective of practice than when different variations of macrolide therapy were combined.

    Agreements and disagreements with other studies or reviews

    A previous meta‐analysis by Florescu evaluated azithromycin for people with CF (Florescu 2009) and included data from four studies also included in this review (Clement 2006; Equi 2002; Saiman 2003; Wolter 2002). Only data from the first arm of the Equi cross‐over study were included (Equi 2002). The authors demonstrated a significant increase in FEV1 with azithromycin compared to placebo (MD 3.53%, 95% CI 0.0 to 7.1%; P = 0.05) and reported significant heterogeneity, which reduced when data from participants chronically infected with P aeruginosa were analysed separately. Whilst we have demonstrated a similar small but significant improvement in the relative change in FEV1, we do not agree with the conclusion that heterogeneity relates to P aeruginosa infection. The reasons for this are:

    1. We have included data from all time points reported in Clement 2006;

    2. We do not feel it is appropriate to combine data from 6 and 12 months (we have reported data from each time point separately); and

    3. We have included data from the Saiman 2010 study (and other smaller studies).

    With these factors, our data were more homogeneous and the impact of chronic P aeruginosa infection was not apparent.

    Adverse events: number of mild

    treatment‐related

    adverse events

    Follow‐up: 6 to 18 months

    Mild adverse events were common across the studies.

    There was no difference between groups in the reporting of diarrhoea, OR 1.43 (95% CI 0.81 to 2.50; 4 studies, 748 participants); sore throat, OR 0.85 (95% CI 0.57 to 1.26; 2 studies, 445 participants); rhinorrhoea, OR 0.91 (95% CI 0.59 to 1.38; 2 studies, 445 participants); headache, OR 0.84 (95% CI 0.56 to 1.27; 3 studies, 527 participants); abdominal pain, OR 0.93 (95% CI 0.61 to 1.41; 4 studies, 748 participants); constipation, OR 1.01 (95% CI 0.06 to 16.34; 1 study, 221 participants); fatigue, OR 0.66 (95% CI 0.39 to 1.09; 2 studies, 445 participants); nasal congestion, OR 1.07 (95% CI 0.72 to 1.58; 2 studies, 445 participants); vomiting, OR 0.88 (95% CI 0.56 to 1.40; 4 studies, 748 participants); hearing impairment, OR 1.13 (95% CI 0.07 to 18.31; 1 study, 185 participants); or tinnitus, OR 1.13 (95% CI 0.07 to 18.31; 1 study, 185 participants).

    Adverse events more common in the azithromycin group included nausea, OR 1.69 (95% CI 0.99 to 2.87; 2 studies, 445 participants); and wheezing, OR 2.13 (95% CI 1.07 to 4.25; 2 studies, 445 participants).

    Adverse events less common in the azithromycin group included cough, OR 0.46 (95% CI 0.30 to 0.69; 2 studies, 445 participants); and fever, OR 0.65 (95% CI 0.43 to 0.97; 3 studies, 527 participants).

    CFQ‐R: Cystic Fibrosis Questionnaire ‐ Revised; CI: confidence interval; FEV1: forced expiratory volume in 1 second; HR: hazard ratio; IV: intravenous; MD: mean difference; NA: not applicable; OR: odds ratio; PA: Pseudomonas aeruginosa; QoL: quality of life; SD: standard deviation.

    GRADE Working Group grades of evidence
    High certainty : we are very confident that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.
    Moderate certainty : we are moderately confident in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect, but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.
    Low certainty : our confidence in the effect estimate is limited: the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.
    Very low certainty: we have very little confidence in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.

    a. Downgraded once for indirectness as the majority of participants were 18 years or younger. Only 1 study included adults and it is unclear whether the results would be applicable to an adult population.

    b. Downgraded once for imprecision as most studies reported adverse events, but they were not reported in the same way and we could only include 4 in our meta‐analysis which limited our sample size; there was heterogeneity within the results.

    c. Downgraded once for imprecision due to a small number of participants from a single trial

    New acquisition of CF pathogens: PA

    Follow‐up: 6 months

    See comments

    The study stated only that PA was reported in 66% of participants at baseline and there was no difference between the groups. The percentage did not change over the course of the study.

    Need for additional antibiotics

    This outcome was not reported.

    QoL: change in CFQ score

    Follow‐up: 6 months

    There was no difference between groups across any domain except for the physical domain, where there was an improvement in the weekly group compared to the daily group of 8.2 points, P = 0.02.

    *The basis for the assumed risk (e.g. the median control group risk across studies) is provided in footnotes. The corresponding risk (and its 95% CI) is based on the assumed risk in the comparison group and the relative effect of the intervention (and its 95% CI).
    CFQ: Cystic Fibrosis Questionnaire; CI: confidence interval; FEV1: forced expiratory volume in one second; NA: not applicable; PA: Pseudomonas aeruginosa; QoL: quality of life; SD: standard deviation.

    GRADE Working Group grades of evidence
    High certainty : we are very confident that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.
    Moderate certainty : we are moderately confident in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect, but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.
    Low certainty : our confidence in the effect estimate is limited: the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.
    Very low certainty: we have very little confidence in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.

    a. Downgraded once for imprecision due to low participant numbers in a single study
